Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Development and Support of the MB-System Software Package for Processing and Display of Swath Mapping Sonar Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
MB-System is an open source software package that enables the user to manipulate, process, display, and analyze swath sonar bathymetry and sidescan data. Renewal of support for MB-System allows upgrades that take advantage of recent hardware improvements including: addition of new data formats; uses beyond standard seafloor mapping (e.g. water column mapping), evolving computer architecture which, with the planned upgrades, will lead to increased program performance. Outputs for new real-time data display capability will be added for the first time.

In contrast to when MB-System was first developed, there are now commercial software packages available to process swath sonar data. However, Geoscience researchers continue to require capabilities that are not available elsewhere- multiple survey handling, access to and ability to adjust filtering parameters- as well as needing a low cost method to conduct this type of work. Scientists can share in the development of MB-System modules and this provides a vibrant exchange of information and keeps the package well-tuned to user needs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
MB-System is an open source software package for the processing and display of seafloor mapping data, particularly including bathymetry and backscatter imagery data derived from multibeam, interferometry, and sidescan sonars. The source code for MB-System is freely available (for free) by download from the project web pages or from the source code repository (links below).

MB-System was originally developed at the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University (L-DEO) and is now a collaborative effort between the Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute (MBARI), University of New Hampshire and MARUM. The National Science Foundation has supported MB-System development since 1993, including this award which was active from 2013 through 2018. The Packard Foundation has provided the primary support for MB-System through MBARI since 1998.

The goal of the  MB-System project is to provide open source software that enables three kinds of work:

1)   The processing, display and interpretation of swath mapping data as part of science projects within the oceanographic research community. 

2)   Innovation in the collection and processing of seafloor mapping data within the academic seafloor mapping community.

3)   Management of large and diverse holdings of swath mapping data by data archives such as the Interdisciplinary Earth Data Alliance (IEDA) and NOAA's National Centers for Environmental Information (NCEI)

The sensor technology used for seafloor mapping from ships and from subsea robots has been evolving rapidly in recent years, making it necessary to continuously upgrade software like MB-System with new capabilities. Similarly rapid changes in computers and operating systems also make constant maintenance necessary in order to simply keep the software operational. Up-to-date documentation is also necessary to enable the utility of software for oceanographic researchers supported by the NSF.

Among the issues addressed by new capabilities developed during this grant are the greatly increased amount of data recorded by seafloor mapping sonars, and the difficult navigational issues associated with surveys conducted using submerged robotic vehicles, which do not have access to GPS underwater and thus depend on inertial navigation. The attached figures show multibeam bathymetry collected with NSF funding by the National Deep Submergence Facility?s autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV) Sentry over Loihi Seamount, offshore Hawaii. The first figure shows an MB-System program called MBeditviz being used to edit the bathymetry. THe left view overlays AUV tracklines on a map view of the bathymetry; the right view shows the 3D editing window for the raw sonar soundings that make up the map. The red soundings have been identified as incorrect, and the black soundings as good. The second figure shows a 3D perspective view of the AUV bathymetry data after editing.

The MB-System website is located at:

https://www.mbari.org/products/research-software/mb-system/

The MB-System source code repository is at:

https://github.com/dwcaress/MB-System
